{{also|nách|nach-}} ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|goh|nāh}} with preservation of word-final ''-h'' as ''-ch''; thus pertaining to modern {{m|de|nah||near}} (from Old High German inflected ''nāh-''). Cognate with {{cog|nl|na}}, {{cog|en|nigh}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/naːx/}} {{a|generally}} * {{IPA|de|/nax/}} {{a|as a preposition, unless stressed}} * {{audio|de|De-nach.ogg|audio}} ===Preposition=== {{head|de|preposition}} {{tlb|de|+ dative}} # [[after]], [[past]] {{gloss|later in time}} #: {{ux|de|Viertel nach sechs|translation=a quarter past six}} #: {{ux|de|nach einer Woche|translation=after a week}} # [[after]], [[behind]] {{gloss|in sequence}} #: {{ux|de|B kommt nach A.|translation=B comes after A.}} # [[to]], [[towards]] (with geographical names; see usage notes below) #: {{ux|de|die Flucht nach Ägypten|translation=the flight into Egypt}} # [[according to]]; guided by #* '''1918''', [[w:de:Elisabeth von Heyking|Elisabeth von Heyking]], ''[[s:de:Die Orgelpfeifen|Die Orgelpfeifen]]'', in: Zwei Erzählungen, Phillipp Reclam jun. Verlag, page 19: #*: Die eigenen Zimmer hatten sich die Enkel '''nach''' persönlichem Geschmack eingerichtet. #*:: The grandchildren had furnished their own rooms according to their personal taste. # [[by]] [[the]] [[authority]] [[of]]; [[following]] #: {{ux|de|die Analyse nach Marx|translation=the analysis following Marx}} # {{lb|de|with verbs of sensual perception}} [[like]] (see usage notes below) #: ''Das riecht '''nach''' Knoblauch.'' – This smells '''like''' garlic. # [[for]] {{qual|indicating desire for an object}} #: '''''nach''' etwas greifen'' — “to reach for something” #: '''''nach''' etwas streben'' - “to strive for/after something” #: '''''nach''' etwas suchen'' - “to search for something” ====Usage notes==== * {{sense|to, towards}} The directional preposition {{m|de|nach}} is now used chiefly with geographical names that do not have an article with them: ''nach Ägypten, nach Hamburg,'' etc. Only in elevated, literary style are there remnants of a freer use of ''nach'': ::: ''nach dem Irak'' (“to Iraq”) — for which usually: {{m|de|[[in]] den Irak}} ::: ''nach dem Schloss'' (“to the castle”) — for which usually: {{m|de|[[zum]] Schloss}}. : At times, this use of ''nach'' conveys the implication that the destination is not reached. Thus: ''Er fuhr zum Schloss.'' – “He travelled to the castle [and arrived there].” But: ''Er fuhr nach dem Schloss.'' – “He travelled towards the castle [and may or may not have arrived].” * Directional ''nach'' with personal names (or names of shops etc.) is found in the regional vernaculars of north-western Germany: ''nach Peter'' (“to Peter's house”). This is nonstandard usage. * {{sense|like}} There may be a slight semantic distinction between the use of {{m|de|nach}} and {{m|de|wie}} after a verb of sensual perception. The following phrases both translate to English as “This feels like silk”, but compare the different implications: ''Das fühlt sich nach Seide an.'' (“This feels like silk, and it probably is.”) ''Das fühlt sich an wie Seide.'' (“This feels like silk, although it’s probably something else.”) This distinction is not a strict one, however. ===Postposition=== {{head|de|postposition|preceded by dative}} # [[according to]] #: {{ux|de|meiner Meinung nach|in my opinion|inline=1}} ===Adverb=== {{de-adv}} # {{lb|de|in compound verbs}} [[after]], [[behind]], [[later]], [[next to]] #: {{ux|de|Meine Uhr geht '''nach'''.|My watch is slow.}} ====Derived terms==== {{der3|de|nachdem|nachher|danach|nach und nach}} ===Related terms=== * {{l|de|nach-}} ---- ==Irish== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|ga|ná}} {{qualifier|Munster; all senses}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|ga|sga|nach}}, from {{inh|ga|cel-pro|*nekʷe}}, a combination of {{der|ga|ine-pro|*ne|pos=negative particle}} and {{m|ine-pro|*-kʷe||and}}; compare {{cog|la|neque}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|ga|/n̪ˠax/}} ===Conjunction=== {{head|ga|conjunction}} {{qualifier|triggers {{ga-mut-link|e}}; used with the dependent form of an irregular verb if there is one}} # [[that]]...[[not]] {{qualifier|introduces a negative [[subordinate clause]]; the negation of {{m|ga|go}}}}. #: {{ux|ga|Dúirt sé '''nach''' raibh carr aige.|He said that he didn’t have a car.}} ===Particle=== {{head|ga|particle|cat2=interrogative particles}} {{qualifier|triggers {{ga-mut-link|e}}; used with the dependent form of an irregular verb if there is one}} # [[not]] {{qualifier|in questions}} #: {{ux|ga|'''Nach''' bhfuil ocras ort?|Are you not hungry?}} #: {{ux|ga|Chonaic mé í, '''nach''' bhfaca?|I saw her, didn’t I?}} ===Particle=== {{head|ga|particle|cat2=interrogative particles}} {{qualifier|copular form}} # [[isn't|isn’t]]...?/[[whether]]/[[if]] [[it]] [[is]]... {{qualifier|introduces negative questions, both direct and indirect}} #: {{ux|ga|'''Nach''' maith leat bainne?|Don’t you like milk?}} #: {{ux|ga|Níl a fhios agam an miste dó nó '''nach''' miste.|I don’t know if it matters to him or not.}} # [[who]]/[[which]] [[isn't|isn’t]]... {{qualifier|introduces negative relative clauses, both direct and indirect}} #: {{ux|ga|an bhean '''nach''' múinteoir í|the woman who isn’t a teacher|inline=1}} #: {{ux|ga|an bhean '''nach''' maith léi bainne|the woman who doesn’t like milk|inline=1}} ====Related terms==== {{ga-copular forms}} ===References=== * {{R:ga:ODonaill}} * {{R:DIL|32907|head=2 nach, nách (‘not’)}} * {{R:DIL|32908|head=3 nach, nách (‘who/which ... not’)}} * {{R:DIL|32909|head=4 nach, nách (‘that ... not’)}} * {{R:DIL|32910|head=5 nach, nách (‘isn’t?, doesn’t?’)}} ---- ==Luxembourgish== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|lb|goh|nāh}} (compare {{cog|de|nach}}, {{m|de|noch||still}}). ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|lb|/nɑχ/}} * {{rhymes|lb|ɑχ}} ===Adverb=== {{head|lb|adverb}} # [[still]] #: {{ux|lb|Ech léieren '''nach''' Lëtzebuergesch.|I'm '''still''' learning Luxembourgish.}} # [[yet]] # [[just]] ===Conjunction=== {{head|lb|conjunction}} # [[nor]] #* [http://www.cathol.lu/spip.php?page=article&id_article=1588&psn_f=contexte&psn_livre=Mt&psn_cvgr=005035&psn_d=77b05fd2bcd3957032fd8ca8098d7073 Luxembourgish translation of Matthew 5:35]: #*: {{ux|lb|'''nach''' bei der Äerd, well dat ass d'Bänkelche fir seng Féiss, '''nach''' bei Jerusalem, well dat ass deem grousse Kinnek seng Stad.|'''nor''' by the earth, because it is the footstool for his feet, '''nor''' by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King.}} ====Usage notes==== * Often used with {{m|lb|weder||neither}}. ---- ==Old Irish== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|sga|cel-pro|*nekʷos||someone, something}}; compare {{m|sga|nech||someone}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|sga|/n͈ax/}} ===Determiner=== {{head|sga|determiner|cat2=indefinite determiners}} # [[some]], [[any]] #* {{RQ:sga-gloss|Wb|23|b|12}} #*: {{quote|sga|it essamnu de ar ro·fitetar is ar '''nach''' n-indocbáil móir fo·daimim-se inso|i.e. they are the more fearless, for they know that it is for some great glory that I endure this}} ====Inflection==== {{sga-decl-nach}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|sga|na ní}} ===Verb=== {{head|sga|verb form}} # {{alt sp|sga|nách|t=that (it) is not}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:DIL|32906|head=1 nach}} * {{R:sga:Thurneysen|s=489|pp=309–10}} ---- ==Scottish Gaelic== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|gd|sga|nach}}, from {{inh|gd|cel-pro|*ne-kʷe}}, a combination of negative particle *ne and conjunction *kʷe; compare {{cog|la|neque}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|gd|/nax/}} ===Particle=== {{head|gd|particle}} # [[not]] ====Usage notes==== * Used with the [[dependent]] form of a verb to produce a [[negative]] question. *: {{ux|gd|'''Nach''' eil an t-acras ort?|inline=1|Are you not hungry?}} *: {{ux|gd|Chunnaic mi i, '''nach''' fhaca?|inline=1|I saw her, didn't I?}} ===Conjunction=== {{head|gd|conjunction}} # that not ====Usage notes==== * Used with the [[dependent]] form of a verb to introduce a negative [[subordinate clause]]. The negation of {{m|gd|gu}}. *: {{ux|gd|Bha e ag ràdh '''nach''' robh càr aige.|inline=1|He said that he didn't have a car.}} ===References=== * {{R:Dwelly}} * {{R:DIL|32907|head=2 nach, nách (‘not’)}} * {{R:DIL|32908|head=3 nach, nách (‘who/which ... not’)}} * {{R:DIL|32909|head=4 nach, nách (‘that ... not’)}} * {{R:DIL|32910|head=5 nach, nách (‘isn’t?, doesn’t?’)}}
